column1: #Text=[0163] In addition, the spatial resolution of photoacoustic images can be improved since the optical fibers 71 are arranged at a high density.
#Text=[0165] In the first to fourth embodiments, the optical scanning unit 13 moves the irradiation position on the subject 7, by sequentially selecting the plurality of arrayed optical fibers 71.
#Text=This method requires using many optical fibers 71 in the waveguide unit 14 and using the optical scanning unit 13 for selecting the fibers 71.
#Text=[0166] The fifth embodiment has been designed to solve this problem in providing irradiation light.
#Text=Irradiation light in the photoacoustic imaging method has almost homogeneous properties over a wide range.
#Text=The spatial resolution of a photoacoustic image is determined by the convergence of acoustic waves in conversion elements 54.
#Text=The fifth embodiment employs the same method of receiving acoustic waves as in the first embodiment.
#Text=[0167] The method of forming irradiation light in the fifth embodiment will be outlined, with reference to FIGS. 12A and 12B.
#Text=FIG. 12A represents the positional relationship between a slit plate 78 and the conversion elements 54.
#Text=FIG. 12B is a schematic diagram of the applicator 70 used in the embodiment.
#Text=An electroacoustic conversion unit 23 has an optically transparent, like the one utilized in the fourth embodiment.
